items.title: it is important to know what we are
Patch 13.2.1: Flurbo is here?!
items.content_html:
Jolly Jinglefest to everyone out there who's still enjoying Orb Minders: Weavecast in its FOURTH YEAR! With the year winding down, but the Jinglefest season heating up, we've got one more announcement for the community this year that we think might just make your holidays a little more merry.

Patch 13.2.1 on Tuesday of COURSE features the bugfix that will allow us to FINALLY restore Rince the Skin-Flayer to the Mercenaries pool (when the Witching Hour remains unbanned by your warband, of course). We appreciate your patience while ol' Rinny has had to sit on the bench due to that exploit we all caught thanks to SneakyPete's viral Twitch clip. But if the whole idea of a bugfix release is putting you to sleep... don't check out just yet, because there may be a special little guy who's tagging along for the ride!

Flurbo is purely cosmetic, adorably cuddly, and is ready to be your best pal.

Flurbo grants NO ADVANTAGE in-game, is a purely optional purchase, and after you dismiss one shop notification about "new items", we won't ever nag you about its availability again.

Flurbo was hand-animated by longtime community member Kendall Price, who's never done professional work in the industry before this moment. This addition to their resume represents the start of us paying back everything they've contributed up until this point purely for the love of the community. Thanks Kendall!

Flurbo is your friend. Its design was done under the supervision of a record seventeen sensitivity consultants.

Nothing can possibly go wrong with Flurbo's launch, and we won't allow you to ruin this for us.

Flurbo approaches. Do NOT resist Flurbo.

items.content_html:
my brain: hey
my brain: hey listen up
me: what?
my brain: how come there's not a DJ named "TJ Waxx"
me: because it's stupid, that's why
my brain: hahaha you should post that shit
me: no! it's not even good
my brain: yeah that's the point
me: hmm. one sec (opening a web browser)
me: oof, actually, there is one reference to the concept of a DJ named "TJ Waxx" and it's on the official TJ Maxx Threads account
my brain: ...
me: so you're exactly as funny as the social media team for TJ Maxx
my brain:

items.title: A Sociable Web
items.content_html:
Natalie's post A Sociable Web is a fantastic outline of what's happening on the web, in a small way and with references to the larger state of things on established "platforms", and I want to shove it in everyone's faces and make them read it.

I don't consider myself to be fully participating in its "sociable" ideals yet‚Äîperhaps obviously, since this is a manual post with a single hyperlink and not a "quote post" or whatever. For whatever it might say about me, I've automated/smoothed out the "performance" part of all of this first and have to be more manual and intentional about the social connection bits.

But! I am really looking forward to moving closer and closer to it and it's nice to have a thing to point at when I'm trying to explain to people what I'm spending time thinking about and working on lately instead of just a mess of ideas, ambitious and achievable, that exists in my head and partially implemented on my own domain.

items.title: not-quite-one-month-anniversary roadmap
items.content_html:
inspired by li's roadmap I guess I will share an updated and mostly-off-the-cuff version of mine, based on a quick scan of my original goals and the mountain of todo list items I have accumulated since then:

  • I gotta get h-entry consumption working so I can "reblog" everyone else who's publishing with it (and bully the rest of you into adding support so I can reblog you too)
  • The post editor has some rough styling edges that I would like to sand down a bit. I want the headline and body fields to grow with the post. The buttons are ass and I would like them to not be ass
  • I need to write some static pages for a blogroll and possibly some other stuff? This isn't actually programming or anything, I have no excuse for not doing this sooner
  • I want a "pinned tags" widget that makes sense on the page in both desktop and mobile
  • posts should be editable without using the git repo
  • posts should be draftable (I agree with li, localstorage is probably fine for now, though it would be nice to have some alternate strategy
  • I need to pull out a bunch of blog-specific things that have been hardcoded and put them into Eleventy Data Files so that my blog is more easily customizable and also probably so I can just take this code, .gitignore the Content and Data files, and force-push back into the octobug repo to have a clean working Eleventy base template.
  • I admit I have not been making any progress on also making it possible to use Octobug with an existing static site setup / your own metadata structure. It's going to be kinda hard and finicky and weird and I'm not looking forward to it, sorry!!!!
  • I have a couple other very stupid but pretty funny ideas that I'm going to keep a secret for now ü§´

it's fun that me and a few other people have spent the last ~month tricking each other into using our accumulated programming skills to improve our lives. I mean that genuinely. Ok I really gotta take a shower now bye

items.content_html: is people on Twitch insisting that they cannot possibly interpret sarcasm without a specific emote added to the end of a statement, ESPECIALLY since the same people would insist that the emote is a somehow-working version of the classic "no offense". Sarcasm is a weapon and it should be wielded as such, not lumped in with bad manners that should be ignored

items.title: weekendend
items.content_html:
instead of working on octobug this weekend I

  • cleaned the garage
  • went grocery shopping
  • cleaned the kitchen three times
  • set up, and learned the routine for, the new basement dehumidifier
  • played video games with friends on the internet. TWICE!
  • ate at Fried Egg I'm In Love
  • took a nap
  • watched Ben-Hur (1925) for my movie club

"Wow", you might say. "A life well lived." and you'd be right. except--

now bcj is reblogging things too and I haven't implemented h-entry support yet!

items.title: the gamer's edge
items.content_html:
I think that the true "gamer's edge" is the ability to be able to watch a piece of media that depicts gaming culture and clock at any given moment whether it's authentic or not. the way a person moves their hands while playing a certain genre of game. the fidelity/depth of sound design relative to the graphical fidelity. the precise level of narrative irony vs the game's supposed release date / mainstream appeal.

but then if that is so then there is also a "knitter's edge", a "philatelist's edge", a "podcast fan's edge", and so on for all communities. and the most popular person among each of those worlds must be declared the edgelord

items.title: We are always using RSS again
items.content_html:
via natalie, in reply to me:

I've been surprised how many people I've seen posting about how they're using RSS again. I guess even when talking about "the heyday of RSS" I was assuming that it was mostly more people joining and not using it than people stopping that caused its decline. I for one have been using RSS pretty much daily since the early 00s.

I would say I fall off of daily RSS reading and then hop back on something like 3-4 times a year and have been since Google Reader died in 2013. It didn‚Äôt help that most of the people I knew personally stopped blogging (tho I‚Äôm also LARGELY guilty of that‚Äî I have been in the 3-to-4 posts a year camp on my primary self-hosted blog) and so my RSS feeds are mostly journalism, news, some weird accumulated tumblr pages, the random people I follow but don‚Äôt know who HAVE been blogging faithfully all this time, and (as the newsletter rebirth exploded and Feedbin added support for them) all the email newsletters I‚Äôm over-subscribed to.

So I‚Äôve been a paid user of Feedbin since something like 2015? I love it, but I also like to do a lot of things in my life and am definitely overcommitted to work and hobbies and family/housekeeping. Things fall by the wayside and as Cohost became a decent way for me to feel ‚Äúaware‚Äù of what was happening online I fell back into one of my periods of less RSS reading.

As Cohost was wrapping up I subscribed to almost every feed I saw people linking to, putting them in a new folder in Feedbin for just them. When I added the feed I put their Cohost username at the end in parentheses, but last night I realized that I wanted to flip it‚Äî I put @username at the front and then put all their carefully considered blog titles in parentheses after that. That small change makes me feel a little bit closer to everyone, as silly as it sounds. (I don‚Äôt consider this blog to have a ‚Äútitle‚Äù per se, btw‚Äî I think topposts dot net is fine for now)

PS I‚Äôm hoping by the end of the weekend I‚Äôll have working h-entry post embeds like Natalie does!! It‚Äôs so cool to see it working at the link at the top of the post and if you haven‚Äôt checked out her blog overall you really should!

items.title: Untitled Post
items.content_html:
there's this weird compulsion where the moment I think I'm making something that might be interesting, I want to polish it to a shine in a way that will make it possible for other people to use it. Despite the fact that it will require an intense and detail-oriented effort to go back and revisit almost every decision, definitely every cut corner, and figure out the "right" way to do it. the error cases to handle. the worries that if I let the software fail, it could hurt someone else.

It sucks! It sucks to feel that weight for absolutely no reason, despite the fact that what you are making is mid, that your knowledge is cobbled together from a bizarre bombardment of information that you've exposed yourself to over your career, both technical and political, that realistically no one cares and if someone does it's because they're already doing the same thing for themselves, or hopefully will someday.

I have to write things into the box and risk them getting posted to the internet in order to test if the software I wrote is working. That's a terrible idea. Automated tests, non-production environments, there are so many ways to make this not be a necessity. And even if not, I can still go delete the file from the repo if I want.

items.title: Octobug does tag autocomplete now
items.content_html:
It gets the list of tags from the server when you open the post editor

And then as you type it shows the tags you've already used so you can more easily "do a bit" that you've done before, and safely put it in the filing cabinet drawer where it belongs.
